Award.AwardTitle: Effect of Inhomogeneous Deformation on the Response of Shape Memory Alloy Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Shape memory alloys (SMA) like NiTi are increasingly being used in a range of applications including damping and energy absorption, biomedical devices, MEMS, morphing of structures, etc. The goal of this project is to study the role of localized deformations associated with stress induced phase transformation in SMAs on the response of such structures. Modeling the response of these structures to bending, torsion and tension/compression loadings requires material models capable of capturing differences between tension and compression, multiaxial loadings and the potential for localized inhomogeneous deformations. Although some aspects of SMA behavior can be captured by modern constitutive models, localized deformation is not. A combination of experiment and analysis will be used to bridge this gap. Experiments on simple SMA structures like bending of tubes, axial crushing of shells, and lateral crushing of clusters of tubes will be used to illustrate how localized deformations alter the structural response. To support the modeling of such nonlinearities a material characterization effort will be undertaken in parallel to form the basis of adding the missing features to constitutive models. This involves measuring the material behavior under tension, compression and biaxial loading histories at different temperatures and rates. The results will form the basis for calibrating a multi-scale modeling effort to include the missing features in robust three-dimensional constitutive models. The models will in turn be tested by implementing them in finite element models to simulate the structural experiments.

The project involves a collaboration between an experimentalist expert on material and structural instabilities and a theorist expert on modeling of smart materials. The cooperation will generate broadly trained researchers who can become future leaders in multidisciplinary research in academia and industry. Undergraduate participation in the project is used to attract them to graduate school. Laboratory demonstrations to high-school pupils including a significant Hispanic representation are used to expand their interest in engineering and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most fascinating properties of shape memory alloys is their ability to deform to far greater extents than most common metals and then return to their original shape. This behavior is called “pseudoelasticity” and was the topic of study during this research program. Specifically, we developed tools to be able to predict the behavior and deformation in basic structures made from shape memory alloys. To do this our research approach was multifaceted, incorporating experimental measurements of the stress-strain behavior of the material, detailed observations of the structural response of tubes being crushed, pulled, and bent, developing mathematical models describing the three-dimensional constitutive response of the material, and applying the constitutive model into numerical finite element simulations to reproduce and predict the structural behaviors observed in the experiments. This holistic approach to SMA structures is unique and constitutes the main intellectual contribution of this project to the subject.

One of the unexpected outcomes of this project was that the incorporation of seemingly small details into the constitutive model had a significant impact on the simulated structural response.  As an example, the included Figure shows both the experimental measurements and simulations of a shape memory alloy tube being compressed to the point where it buckles. The agreement between the experiment and simulation is quite good––Asymmetric in red on the Figure––, but what is hidden is the fact that this level of performance in the simulations is only possible if details about the differences between the tensile and compressive behaviors of the material are incorporated into the constitutive model. This is not intuitive since the structure is entirely under compression, yet a model that is based solely on the compressive behavior of the material does not perform adequately – Symmetric in purple on the Figure.

The intellectual merit of the completed project resides in the experimentally validated constitutive modeling framework that has been developed for shape memory alloys, and the demonstration, by direct comparison to experiments, of the skillful numerical predictions of structural responses. The broader impacts of the work reside in the training of several graduate and undergraduate students, and the exposure of K12 students to the wonders of structures designed and built out of this fascinating material.


Last Modified: 08/14/2018
Modified by: Stelios Kyriakides

Image
  • An example of a NiTi energy absorber. Measured and calculated axial compressive response of a NiTi tube. The structure buckles into lobes as shown in the experimental and calculated configurations, and recovers on unloading.
